content.title: Neuromuscular Blockade in the ICU
content.summary: Neuromuscular blocking agents (NMBAs) paralyze skeletal muscles by blocking acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. In the ICU, they are used for severe ARDS to improve ventilator synchrony, for intubation, and for increased intracranial pressure. Cisatracurium is preferred for infusions due to organ-independent metabolism. Complications include prolonged weakness (ICUAW) and awareness if inadequate sedation.
key_points: Indications: Severe ARDS (ACURASYS trial), intubation, elevated ICP, refractory shivering
Cisatracurium preferred for infusions (organ-independent Hofmann elimination)
ALWAYS ensure adequate sedation and analgesia before paralysis
ACURASYS showed mortality benefit; ROSE trial did not replicate - use remains selective
content.statement: Neuromuscular blockade should be reserved for specific indications where paralysis provides clear benefit, with attention to adequate sedation, monitoring, and minimizing duration to reduce ICU-acquired weakness.

explanation.intuition: NMBAs paralyze patients completely but do NOT provide sedation or pain control - the patient may be fully aware but unable to move. Always sedate deeply before paralyzing. Think of it as removing the body's ability to fight the ventilator in severe ARDS.
explanation.key_insight: The ACURASYS trial (2010) showed mortality benefit with early 48h cisatracurium in severe ARDS. The larger ROSE trial (2019) did not replicate this benefit with current lung-protective practices. Use remains selective for ventilator dyssynchrony despite optimal sedation.
explanation.technical_details: Cisatracurium undergoes Hofmann elimination (spontaneous degradation) independent of renal/hepatic function - preferred for infusion. Succinylcholine is depolarizing (contraindicated in hyperkalemia, burns, denervation). TOF monitoring at ulnar nerve; target 1-2 of 4 twitches for adequate paralysis.

definitions_glossary.neuromuscular_blockade: Pharmacological paralysis of skeletal muscles by blocking neuromuscular junction
definitions_glossary.NMBA: Neuromuscular blocking agent; causes paralysis without sedation or analgesia
definitions_glossary.cisatracurium: Non-depolarizing NMBA; organ-independent metabolism; preferred for infusion
definitions_glossary.rocuronium: Non-depolarizing NMBA; rapid onset; reversed by sugammadex
definitions_glossary.vecuronium: Non-depolarizing NMBA; hepatic metabolism; older agent
definitions_glossary.succinylcholine: Depolarizing NMBA; rapid onset/offset; hyperkalemia risk
definitions_glossary.train_of_four: Monitoring technique using 4 electrical stimuli to assess paralysis depth
definitions_glossary.Hofmann_elimination: Spontaneous drug degradation independent of organ function
definitions_glossary.ICU_acquired_weakness: Muscle weakness developing during critical illness; worsened by NMBAs
definitions_glossary.ventilator_dyssynchrony: Patient-ventilator mismatch; may indicate need for paralysis
definitions_glossary.awareness: Patient consciousness during paralysis; prevented by adequate sedation

pathophysiology.mechanism: NMBAs block acetylcholine binding at nicotinic receptors on motor end plates → inability to generate muscle action potentials → paralysis

indications: Severe ARDS with ventilator dyssynchrony despite sedation (P/F <150)

monitoring.train_of_four: Apply at ulnar nerve q4-6h; target 1-2 of 4 twitches
monitoring.sedation: BIS monitor if available; ensure adequate sedation

complications.prolonged_weakness: ICU-acquired weakness; worsened by steroids + NMBAs
complications.awareness: Paralyzed but conscious; ensure deep sedation
complications.corneal_injury: Cannot blink; use lubricants, tape lids

definition.@value: The use of neuromuscular blocking agents to produce skeletal muscle paralysis for specific indications in critically ill patients

learning_objectives: List indications for neuromuscular blockade in the ICU
Select appropriate NMBA for clinical scenario
Recognize and prevent complications of NMBAs
clinical_pearls: NEVER paralyze without adequate sedation - awareness is devastating
Succinylcholine contraindicated >24h after burns, crush injury, denervation
ACURASYS showed benefit; ROSE did not - use selectively in severe ARDS
